data.event: Werneck includes the following divisions: Eckartshausen Egenhausen Ettleben Eßleben Mühlhausen Rundelshausen Schleerieth Schnackenwerth Schraudenbach Stettbach Vasbühl Werneck Zeuzleben The first written record of Werneck is dated 10 August 1223, as a fief granted by Bodo of Ravensburg, confirmed by the Pope on 9 April 1223.

event.title: confirmed by the Pope on 9 April 1223

data.event: Werneck includes the following divisions: Eckartshausen Egenhausen Ettleben Eßleben Mühlhausen Rundelshausen Schleerieth Schnackenwerth Schraudenbach Stettbach Vasbühl Werneck Zeuzleben The first written record of Werneck is dated 10 August 1223, as a fief granted by Bodo of Ravensburg, confirmed by the Pope on 9 April 1223.

event.title: was sacked in the Peasants' War in 1525

data.event: A fort located there was sacked in the Peasants' War in 1525 and then seized and burnt down by Albert Alcibiades, Margrave of Brandenburg-Kulmbach in 1553.

event.title: seized and burnt down by Albert Alcibiades, Margrave of Brandenburg-Kulmbach in 1553

data.event: A fort located there was sacked in the Peasants' War in 1525 and then seized and burnt down by Albert Alcibiades, Margrave of Brandenburg-Kulmbach in 1553.
It was rebuilt in 1601 under Prince Bishop Julius Echter von Mespelbrunn, but was again destroyed by fire in 1723 and merely patched up in 1724.
It was rebuilt in 1601 under Prince Bishop Julius Echter von Mespelbrunn, but was again destroyed by fire in 1723 and merely patched up in 1724.
